questiontext.text: A molecule bears an aldehyde and an ester. Which single reagent-condition set most directly gives the primary alcohol from the aldehyde with minimal ester reduction at low temperature?

generalfeedback.text: At −78 °C, DIBAL-H reduces aldehydes rapidly, while esters are reduced more slowly and often stop at the aldehyde after controlled quench; this enables chemoselective reduction of the aldehyde in the presence of an ester. LiAlH4 and LiBH4 are too reactive and reduce esters; NaBH4 is mild but may still reduce aldehydes while leaving esters mostly untouched, not delivering the desired selectivity profile as reliably as low-temperature DIBAL control.

answer.text: LiAlH4, THF, 0–25 °C
NaBH4, MeOH, 0–25 °C
DIBAL-H, toluene, −78 °C, then MeOH quench
LiBH4, THF, reflux

questiontext.text: In a substrate containing both an aldehyde and a ketone, which condition favors chemoselective nucleophilic addition at the aldehyde?

generalfeedback.text: Aldehydes are more electrophilic and less sterically hindered than ketones, so a strong, fast nucleophile at low temperature (e.g., RLi) will preferentially add to the aldehyde under kinetic control. Softer cuprates may favor conjugate additions and be less reactive to simple carbonyls; hindered Grignards at reflux can cause side reactions; “bulky, less basic hydride” is vague and may not ensure selectivity in C–C bond formation.

answer.text: Use of a hindered Grignard reagent at reflux
Use of a softer cuprate at −78 °C
Use of a bulky, less basic hydride at −78 °C
Use of a strong organolithium at −78 °C

questiontext.text: For EAS on a ring bearing both –OCH3 and –NO2, the predominant regioisomer with Br2/FeBr3 is expected at:

generalfeedback.text: –OCH3 is a strong ortho/para director and activates the ring, while –NO2 is a strong meta director but deactivating; the activated sites ortho/para to –OCH3 are favored for electrophilic substitution, typically overriding the deactivated positions influenced by –NO2. Thus bromination occurs mainly ortho/para to –OCH3.

answer.text: Meta to –OCH3 due to deactivation by –NO2
Ortho/para to –OCH3 because it is strongly activating and outcompetes –NO2
Meta to –NO2 because –NO2 is a meta director and dominates
Ortho to –NO2 due to its strong –I effect

questiontext.text: Addition of a nucleophile to an α-chiral aldehyde lacking coordinating heteroatoms usually follows:

generalfeedback.text: Absent coordinating substituents, classical Cram steric approach control often predicts major diastereomer via attack from the less hindered face at the carbonyl. Chelation control becomes important with α-alkoxy/amine substituents under Lewis acidic conditions; Felkin–Anh refines Cram by including electronic effects with electronegative α-substituents.

answer.text: Chelation-controlled model with synclinal approach
Cram’s steric approach model favoring attack from the least hindered face
Prelog’s rule mandating opposite facial selectivity to Cram
Felkin–Anh model dominated exclusively by electronic effects with no steric input

questiontext.text: A meso-1,2-diol undergoes selective monoacylation by a lipase to give a single optically active monoester. This process exemplifies:

generalfeedback.text: Selective transformation of one enantiotopic OH in a meso diol breaks symmetry to give a chiral product, i.e., desymmetrization. Classical salt resolution addresses racemates; simple kinetic resolution caps at 50% conversion to isolate one enantiomer; DKR needs in situ racemization of the unreacted enantiomer, which is not a meso case.

answer.text: Classical resolution via diastereomeric salt formation
Kinetic resolution limited to 50% theoretical maximum
Desymmetrization generating chirality from a meso substrate
Dynamic kinetic resolution requiring racemization catalyst

questiontext.text: Choosing between Boc and Cbz for protecting a primary amine in a sequence that uses strong acid but prohibits hydrogenation, the better choice is:

generalfeedback.text: Boc is acid-labile and typically removed by TFA; it avoids hydrogenation. Cbz is removed by hydrogenolysis, which is prohibited by the sequence; it is not generally base-labile nor acid-labile like tert-butyl esters.

answer.text: Boc, because it is removed by TFA and avoids hydrogenolysis
Cbz, because it is removed under basic conditions
Boc, because it requires hydrogenolysis for removal
Cbz, because it is acid-labile like tert-butyl esters

questiontext.text: A racemic secondary alcohol is subjected to lipase-catalyzed acetate formation, giving 40% conversion and 96% ee in the acetate. The selectivity factor s is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: For kinetic resolution, s = ln[(1−c)(1−ee_s)]/ln[(1−c)(1+ee_s)] or using product ee and conversion relations; at c = 0.40 and product ee_p = 0.96, the calculated s is approximately in the 10–12 range; 12 is the closest of the options. Lower values underestimate the high enantiodiscrimination implied by 96% ee at only 40% conversion.

questiontext.text: In an Evans auxiliary-controlled aldol using a Z-boron enolate, the dominant diastereomer arises from a Zimmerman–Traxler chair in which:

generalfeedback.text: Under boron-mediated aldol conditions with Z-boron enolates, the chair-like Zimmerman–Traxler transition state typically delivers syn aldol products; the Evans auxiliary enforces facial selectivity, enhancing diastereocontrol. E enolates generally favor anti products in this model.

answer.text: Both large groups occupy axial positions, giving anti product
The chiral auxiliary biases approach to give syn aldol from Z enolate
The enolate geometry is irrelevant to syn/anti outcome
E enolates give syn aldol preferentially under boron mediation

questiontext.text: In a proline-catalyzed asymmetric aldol between acetone and p-nitrobenzaldehyde, the origin of enantioselectivity is best attributed to:

generalfeedback.text: Proline forms a chiral enamine with the ketone donor; this enamine adds to the aldehyde (often H-bond activated), and the chiral environment dictates enantiofacial approach, giving enantioenriched aldol products. Iminium activation can be involved with α,β-unsaturated acceptors, but the core mode here is enamine catalysis.

answer.text: Iminium activation of the aldehyde by protonation alone
Enamine formation from acetone and chiral enamine addition to the aldehyde
Metal–ligand backbonding lowering the aldehyde LUMO
Single-electron transfer to generate radical ions

questiontext.text: For competing 1,2- vs. 1,4-addition of MeLi and Me2CuLi to cyclohexenone at −78 °C, the expected major products are:

generalfeedback.text: Hard, highly basic nucleophiles like MeLi favor direct 1,2-addition to the carbonyl, whereas softer cuprates like Me2CuLi favor conjugate (1,4) addition to enones at low temperature, illustrating reagent-controlled regioselectivity. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d56907a9-060e-4d86-bddd-81839e191ded/organic_unit_08.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/710f5898-842c-4d82-ad4a-29c3aa7a6003/organic_unit_06.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0d13af76-414f-4c3b-8d8c-2f6b625d3637/organic_unit_05.txt)

answer.text: MeLi: 1,4-addition; Me2CuLi: 1,2-addition
MeLi: 1,2-addition; Me2CuLi: 1,4-addition
Both give predominantly 1,2-addition under kinetic control
Both give predominantly 1,4-addition due to conjugation
